element.name: !DOCTYPE
element.description: Specifies the HTML standard that should be used for this document.
element.example:
This example shows a !DOCTYPE element for a strict XHTML document:


			<!DOCTYPE "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd" >
element.remarks: <!DOCTYPE /> is actually an XML element. Use this element as the first element in all XHTML documents.

element.name: a
element.description: Specifies either a hyperlink or a target for a hyperlink.
element.example:
Hyperlink example

This example shows a hyperlink to an external web site that will open in a new browser window:

 <a href="http://www.aptana.com" target="_blank">Aptana's web site</a>

Email example

This example shows an email hyperlink that will create a new email to be sent to the "mailto:" address:

 <a href="mailto:sales@aptana.com">Aptana Sales</a>

Target example

This example shows an anchor that is set up to be a target for a hyperlink:

 <a href="mailto:sales@aptana.com">Aptana Sales</a>
element.remarks: An anchor can define either a hyperlink, including an email address, a target for a hyperlink, or both.

element.name: abbr
element.description: Specifies that a string is an abbreviation for a longer word or phrase.
element.example:
This example defines "lab" as an abbreviation for "labrador retriever":

My dog is a <abbr title="labrador retriever">lab</abbr>.
element.remarks: The <abbr></abbr> tag is typically only used in formatting with CSS style sheets and with scripts. Similar to the <acronym></acronym> tag.

element.name: acronym
element.description: Specifies that a string is an acronym for a word or phrase.
element.example:
This example defines the acronym :

One such hot technology is <abbr title="Asynchronous JavaScript and XML"> </abbr>.
element.remarks: The <acronym></acronym> tag is typically only used in formatting with CSS style sheets and with scripts. Similar to the <abbr></abbr> tag.

element.name: address
element.description: Specifies name and address information related to the HTML document.
element.example:
This example defines an address for the company Aptana:

 <address> Aptana <br />
8899 University Center Lane <br /> 
Suite 300 <br />
San Diego, CA 92122
</address>
element.remarks: The <address></address> tag is typically only used in formatting with CSS style sheets and with scripts.

element.name: applet
element.description: Defines a Java applet object.
element.example:
This example defines center-aligned applet named "myApplet":

<applet code="/java/myApplet.class" align="center" height="350" width="350"> 
	<p> Install Java before trying to view this applet.</p>
</applet>
element.remarks: The <applet></applet> tag is deprecated with W3C-compliant HTML 4.01. Use <object></object> instead.

element.name: area
element.description: Used for image maps to define a clickable area on an image.
element.example:
This example defines an area map named "navigation" with links to a home page, product page, and support page:

 <map name="navigation" > 
	<area shape="rect" coords="10,10,100,100" href="index.htm"  />
	<area shape="rect" coords="10,100,100,190" href="products.htm"  />
	<area shape="rect" coords="10,200,100,280" href="support.htm"  />
</map>
element.remarks: Remember to self-close your <area / > tags.

element.name: article
element.description: Specifies an article element that represents a self-contained composition in a document, page, application, or site.
element.example:
The Very First Rule of Life

If there's a microphone anywhere near you, assume it's hot and sending whatever you're saying to the world. Seriously.

...

Show comments...
element.remarks: An article could be a forum post, a magazine or newspaper article, a blog entry, a user-submitted comment, an interactive widget or gadget, or any other independent item of content.

element.name: aside
element.description: Specifies a sidebar for tangentially related content
element.example:
Switzerland

Switzerland, a land-locked country in the middle of geographic Europe, has not joined the geopolitical European Union, though it is a signatory to a number of European treaties.
element.remarks: The element can be used for typographical effects like pull quotes or sidebars, for advertising, for groups of nav elements, and for other content that is considered separate from the main content of the page.

element.name: audio
element.description: Specifies an audio player
element.remarks: You can write text inside the start and end audio tags, to show older browser that they do not support this tag.

element.name: b
element.description: Displays the text of the element as boldface text.
element.example:
This example displays the words "Dog menu" and "Pug" in boldface:

From the <b>Dog menu</b>, select <b>Pug.</b>
element.remarks: Use the <b></b> tag to visually emphasize a word or phrase. Similar to the <strong><strong> tag.

element.name: base
element.description: Specifies a base URL for all of the relative URLs in the document to use.
element.example:
This example defines the base URL in this document to be "http:www.aptana.com/docs/", all opening in a new, blank window:

<base href="http://www.aptana.com/docs" target="_blank" />
element.remarks: Use the <base /> tag when you want to define a base URL for the relative URLs in a document. Remember to self-close your <base / > tags.

element.name: basefont
element.deprecated: Use CSS to format fonts instead.
element.description: Specifies the default font for the document.
element.example:
This example defines the base font in this document to be 12pt, Arial, red:

<basefont size="12pt" face="Arial" color="red" />
element.remarks: Not supported in Mozilla or Opera. Use a CSS rule to define a base font, if possible. Remember to self-close your <basefont / > tags.

element.name: bdo
element.description: Specifies the text direction for the document.
element.example:
This example shows a sentence of text that should be rendered from right-to-left:

 <bdo dir="rtl">This text will display from right-to-left.</bdo>
element.remarks: Use <bdo></bdo> to set the text direction to either "left-to-right" or "right-to-left".

element.name: bgsound
element.description: Specifies a background sound to play while loading the document.
element.example:
This example specifies that a sound file called "horns.wav" should play in a loop while loading the page:

<bgsound src="sounds/horns.wav" loop="infinite" />
element.remarks: IE only.

element.name: big
element.description: Increases the font size for the enclosed text.
element.example:
This example displays the sentence "This sentence is big." as big text, relative to the surrounding text:

This sentence is normal-sized. <big>This sentence is big.</big>, This sentence is also normal-sized.
element.remarks: For more options and flexibility with font sizes, use CSS rules, rather than the <big></big> tag.

element.name: blink
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text should blink.
element.example:
This example displays the sentence "This sentence blinks." as blinking text:

 <blink>This sentence blinks.</blink>, This sentence does not blink.
element.remarks: Netscape only. Avoid using the <blink></blink> tag if possible.

element.name: blockquote
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text is a block quotation.
element.example:
This example displays the preamble of the US constitution as a block quote:


<p>All eighth-graders must memorize the preamble to the US constitution: </p>

<blockquote>We the people of the United States, in order to form a more perfect union, establish justice, insure domestic tranquility, provide for the common defense, promote the general welfare, and secure the blessings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity, do ordain and establish this Constitution for the United States of America.</blockquote>
element.remarks: Most browsers will visually display a <blockquote></blockquote> as indented text.

element.name: body
element.description: Specifies the body of the content of the document.
element.example:
This example shows a body element with the background set to an image named "background.gif" and runs the "startup()" function from a linked JS file defined in the head of the document (not shown) when the body loads:

 <body background="images/background.gif" onload="startup();"> <p>Some text...</p> </body>
element.remarks: The <body></body> element is required in all HTML documents. When settting color, font, background properties, use CSS rules when possible, rather than setting them explicitly in the <body&gt</body> tag.

element.name: br
element.description: Specifies a hard line break in the text.
element.example:
This example displays two sentences of text on two separate lines.


This sentence is on the first line.<br / >
This sentence is on the second line.
element.remarks: Remember to self-close your <br / > tags.

element.name: button
element.description: Defines a clickable Button element.
element.example:
Text button example

This example shows a button that has a text label and calls a "clickMe()" function (defined elsewhere) when a user clicks the button:

 <button type="button" onclick="clickMe();" >Click me!</button>

Graphic example

This example shows a button that instead of having a text label, has a graphical "edit.gif" label. It also calls the "clickMe()" function when clicked:

 <button type="button" onclick="clickMe();" > <img src="images/edit.gif" alt="Edit" /> </button>

Submit button example

This example shows button that is equivalent to a "submit" input type. This is useful if you need multiple submit buttons on a form:

 <button type="submit" value="submit" name="submit" >Submit Form</button>
element.remarks: Using <input type="button" /> is more common than using <button> </button> tags. You can enclose an <img /> tag with <button> </button> tags to display an image instead of text on the button.

element.name: canvas
element.description: Specifies a scriptable bitmap canvas

element.name: caption
element.description: Defines a caption within a table.
element.example:
This example shows a table caption for a table that lists dog breeds:


<table> <caption align="bottom" > Types of dogs </caption> 
	<tr> 
		<td>Labrador retriever</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
		<td>Golden retriever </td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
		<td>Pug </td>
	</tr>
</table>
element.remarks: Only use one <caption> </caption> per table.

element.name: center
element.description: Centers the element within the margins of the document or parent element(s).
element.example:
This example centers the text in a sentence:

<center>I have a dog named Jordo.</center>
element.remarks: Use a CSS rule to center an element instead of the <center></center> tags, if possible.

element.name: cite
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text is a citation from another source.
element.example:
This example displays the words "Dog menu" and "Pug" in boldface:

This example is from <cite> JavaScript: The Definitive Guide </cite>.
element.remarks: Use the <cite></cite> tag to define style rules for a citation.

element.name: clipPath
element.description: Specifies the clipping path

element.name: code
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text is programming code and should be formatted appropriately.
element.example:
This example displays words "bar" and "foo" in monospace code format:

Call the function <code> bar </code> on the object <code> foo </code> .
element.remarks: The <code></code> tag does not preserve whitespace in code samples. For multiline code examples, or those with indentation, use the <pre></pre> tag.

element.name: col
element.description: Defines a table column.
element.example:
This example shows a table with the 10px-wide first column center-aligned and the second column left-aligned:


<table>
	<colgroup>
		<col align="center" width="10px" />
		<col align="left" />
	</colgroup> 
	<tr> 
		<td>1.</td> <td>Labrador retriever</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
		<td>2.</td> <td>Golden retriever</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
		<td>3.</td> <td>Pug</td>
	</tr>
</table>
element.remarks: Set any <col /> tags inside of a set of <colgroup> </colgroup> tags.

element.name: colgroup
element.description: Defines a table column group.
element.example:
This example shows a table with the 10px-wide first column center-aligned and the second column left-aligned:


<table>
	<colgroup>
		<col align="center" width="10px" />
		<col align="left" />
	</colgroup> 
	<tr> 
		<td>1.</td> <td>Labrador retriever</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
		<td>2.</td> <td>Golden retriever</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
		<td>3.</td> <td>Pug</td>
	</tr>
</table>
element.remarks: Specify the attributes of any individual columns in a <col /> tag that is nested inside of a set of <colgroup> </colgroup> tags.

element.name: command
element.description: Specifies a command that the user can invoke
element.example: <menu type="toolbar"> <command type="radio" radiogroup="alignment" checked="checked" label="Left" icon="icons/alL.png" onclick="setAlign('left')"> <command type="radio" radiogroup="alignment" label="Center" icon="icons/alC.png" onclick="setAlign('center')"> <command type="radio" radiogroup="alignment" label="Right" icon="icons/alR.png" onclick="setAlign('right')"> <hr> <command type="command" disabled label="Publish" icon="icons/pub.png" onclick="publish()"> </menu>

element.name: comment
element.description: Comments out the enclosed text.
element.example:
This example comments out the sentence text:

<comment> Do not use this format for comments. </comment>.
element.remarks: Deprecated. IE only. Use the <!--><--> tag set to comment out code instead.

element.name: datalist
element.description: Specifies a container for options for combo box control
element.example: <input list="cars" /> <datalist id="cars"> <option value="BMW"> <option value="Ford"> <option value="Volvo"> </datalist>
element.remarks: In the rendering, the datalist element represents nothing and it, along with its children, should be hidden.

element.name: dd
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text is a definition in a definition list.
element.example:
This example shows a definition list with three terms and three definitions:


<dl>
	<dt>  </dt>
		<dd> Asynchronous JavaScript and XML </dd>
	<dt> HTML </dt>
		<dd> Hypertext Markup Language </dd>
	<dt> XML </dt>
		<dd> eXtensible Markup Language </dd>
</dl>
element.remarks: Nest your definitions (<dd> </dd>) in a definition list (<dl> </dl>). Add the definitions after the definition term (<dt> </dt>) tag set.

element.name: del
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text has been deleted.
element.example:
This example shows that the phrase "and a pug" has been deleted:

I like dogs. I have a lab <del> and a pug</del>.
element.remarks: The <del></del> tag only style text to visually show deletions. It does not actually delete the enclosed text.

element.name: details
element.description: Specifies details about a document, or parts of a document.
element.example: Name & Extension:
element.remarks: The details element is not appropriate for footnotes.

element.name: dfn
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text defines a term.
element.example:
This example shows the defining instance of the word "lab":

A <dfn>lab</dfn>, or labrador retriever, is a big, happy, friendly dog.
element.remarks: You can use CSS rules to style the <dfn></dfn> tag.

element.name: dialog
element.description: The dialog element represents a part of an application that a user interacts with to perform a task, for example a dialog box, inspector, or window.

element.name: dir
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text is a directory list of short, unordered items.
element.example:
This example shows a directory list of dog breeds:


<dir>
	<li>Labrador retriever</li>
	<li>Golden retriever</li>
	<li>Pug</li>
</dir>
element.remarks: The <dir></dir> tag is similar to an unordered list (<ul></ul>). Directory lists should contain only short words and phrases and should be no longer than 20 characters. Enclose individiual list items in <li></li> tags.

element.name: div
element.description: Defines a special block of content within a document.
element.example:
This example shows a div containing an image of a golden retriever. This div can then be moved around the page or have other dynamic effects added through JavaScript:


<div id="goldenRetriever" style="position:absolute; left:450px; top:10px; width:150px;height:80px; z-index:1;" >
	<img src="golden.jpg" width="150px" height="80px" />
</div>
element.remarks: Use the <div></div> element to style portions of a page individually and for dynamic effects.

element.name: dl
element.description: Defines a list of definition terms and definitions.
element.example:
This example shows a definition list with three terms and three definitions:


<dl>
	<dt>  </dt>
		<dd>Asynchronous JavaScript and XML </dd>
	<dt>HTML </dt>
		<dd>Hypertext Markup Language </dd>
	<dt>XML </dt>
		<dd>eXtensible Markup Language </dd>
</dl>
element.remarks: Nest your definitions (<dd> </dd>) in a definition list (<dl> </dl>). Add the definitions after the definition term (<dt> </dt>) tag set.

element.name: dt
element.description: Defines a list of definition terms in a definition list.
element.example:
This example shows a definition list with three terms and three definitions:


<dl>
	<dt>  </dt>
		<dd> Asynchronous JavaScript and XML </dd>
	<dt> HTML </dt>
		<dd> Hypertext Markup Language </dd>
	<dt> XML </dt>
		<dd> eXtensible Markup Language </dd>
</dl>
element.remarks: Nest your definitions (<dd> </dd>) in a definition list (<dl> </dl>). Add the definitions after the definition term (<dt> </dt>) tag set.

element.name: em
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text should be emphasized.
element.example:
This example displays the words "labrador retriever" in italics:

A <em>labrador retriever</em> is a big, happy friendly dog.
element.remarks: Use the <em></em> tag to visually emphasize a word or phrase. Similar to the <i><i> tag.

element.name: embed
element.description: Defines an object, such as a multimedia file, embedded in an HTML document.
element.example:
This example defines center-aligned embedded object that plays the "myMovie.mov" file:

 <embed src="myMovie.mov" align="center" height="350" width="350"> 
	<noembed> Please download the appropriate multimedia player.</noembed>
</embed>
element.remarks: Although the <embed></embed> tag is supported by most browsers, it is not W3C-compliant. Use <object></object> to be W3C-compliant.

element.name: fieldset
element.description: Defines a set of related form controls to be grouped together.
element.example:
This example shows a text label that is grouped with a text box:


<fieldset>
	<label>Name:</label>
	<input type="text" id="customerName" name="customerName" />
</fieldset>
element.remarks: Use <fieldset> </fieldset> tags to group form controls together for usability and tabbing.

element.name: figcaption
element.description: Specifies a caption or legend for the rest of the contents of the figcaption element's parent figure element, if any.

element.name: figure
element.description: Specifies a figure tag used to group some elements.
element.example:
In listing 4 we see the primary core interface API declaration.

The API is designed to use UTF-8.
element.remarks: The figure element can thus be used to annotate illustrations, diagrams, photos, code listings, etc, that are referred to from the main content of the document, but that could, without affecting the flow of the document, be moved away from that primary content, e.g. to the side of the page, to dedicated pages, or to an appendix.

element.name: font
element.description: Specifies the font (or font family), color, and size of the enclosed text.
element.example:
This example displays the words "labrador retriever" in 12pt Arial red font:

A <font face="Arial" size="12pt" color="red" >labrador retriever</em> is a big, happy friendly dog.
element.remarks: Use the CSS style sheets to style a font rather than the <font></font> tag if possible.

element.name: footer
element.description: Specifies a footer of a section or document that typically contains the name of the author, the date the document was written and/or contact information.
element.example:
Back to index...

Lorem ipsum

The ipsum of all lorems

A dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat non proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum.

Back to index...
element.remarks: Footers don't necessarily have to appear at the end of a section, though they usually do.

element.name: form
element.description: Defines a form within a document.
element.example:
This example shows a form that collects a customer's name and phone number:


<form action="thankyou.html" name="orderform" id="orderform" method="get" 
onsubmit="return validate();"
onreset="return confirm('Clear all fields and reset form?');">
	<input type="text" id="customerName" name="customerName" />
	<input type="text" id="phoneNumber" name="phoneNumber" />
	<br />
	<input type="submit" name="Submit" id="submit" value="Submit" />
	<input type="reset" name="Reset" id="reset" value="Reset" />
</form>
element.remarks: In addition to <fieldset> </fieldset>, <label> </label>, and <legend> </legend> elements, you can use <table> </table> and <div> </div> elements to improve the layout of a form.

element.name: frame
element.description: Defines a window-like frame (as a child of a frameset).
element.example:
This example shows a frameset containing two frames--a navMenu.htm page and a home page (index.htm). The frameset is split into columns:


<frameset cols="20%, 80%" >
	<frame src="navMenu.htm" name="navMenu" />
	<frame src="index.htm" name="home" />
</frameset>
element.remarks: Define your individual <frame> </frame> elements within a set of <frameset> </frameset>, tags.

element.name: frameset
element.description: Defines a set of window-like frames within a parent window.
element.example:
This example shows a frameset containing two frames--a navMenu.htm page and a home page (index.htm). The frameset is split into columns:


<frameset cols="20%, 80%" >
	<frame src="navMenu.htm" name="navMenu" />
	<frame src="index.htm" name="home" />
</frameset>
element.remarks: Define your individual <frame> </frame> elements within a set of <frameset> </frameset>, tags.

element.name: h1
element.description: Heading Level 1.
element.example:
This example displays the words "Contact Information" as a level 1 heading:

 <h1>Contact Information</h1>
element.remarks: Use the h1-h6 tags to define different levels of headings.

element.name: h2
element.description: Heading Level 2.
element.example:
This example displays the words "Contact Information" as a level 2 heading:

 <h2>Contact Information</h2>
element.remarks: Use the h1-h6 tags to define different levels of headings.

element.name: h3
element.description: Heading Level 3.
element.example:
This example displays the words "Contact Information" as a level 3 heading:

 <h3>Contact Information</h3>
element.remarks: Use the h1-h6 tags to define different levels of headings.

element.name: h4
element.description: Heading Level 4.
element.example:
This example displays the words "Contact Information" as a level 4 heading:

 <h4>Contact Information</h4>
element.remarks: Use the h1-h6 tags to define different levels of headings.

element.name: h5
element.description: Heading Level 5.
element.example:
This example displays the words "Contact Information" as a level 5 heading:

 <h5>Contact Information</h5>
element.remarks: Use the h1-h6 tags to define different levels of headings.

element.name: h6
element.description: Heading Level 6.
element.example:
This example displays the words "Contact Information" as a level 6 heading:

 <h6>Contact Information;</h6>
element.remarks: Use the h1-h6 tags to define different levels of headings.

element.name: head
element.description: Non-rendered part of an HTML document that may contain meta information and may define links to scripts, stylesheets, and other documents.
element.example:
This example shows the <head></head> element for a company home page, including a meta tag, title, and a link to a stylesheet:

 
<head>
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" />
	<title>Aptana Home Page</title>
	<link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css" type="text/css" />
</head>
element.remarks: The <head></head> element must contain a <title></title> element.

element.name: header
element.description: Specifies an introduction to the document
element.example:
Welcome to...

Voidwars!

element.name: hgroup
element.description: Specifies the heading of a section or a document
element.example:
The reality dysfunction

Space is not the only void

Dr. Strangelove

Or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb

element.name: hr
element.description: Creates a horizontal line in the HTML document.
element.example:
This example displays two short text paragraphs divided by a horizontal rule:


			<p>This is my first paragraph.</p> 
			<hr />
			<p>This is my second paragraph.</p>
element.remarks: Use CSS style rules to format your horizontal rules instead of HTML attributes, if possible.

element.name: html
element.description: Defines an HTML document.
element.example:
This example shows a basic, generic HTML document:

 
			<html>
				<head>
					<title>Add Title Here</title>
				</head>
				<body> Add content here. </body>
			</html>
element.remarks: The <html></html> element must contain a <head></head> (with a nested <title></title> element and either a <body></body> element or a <frameset></frameset> element.

element.name: i
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text should be displayed in italics.
element.example:
This example displays the words "labrador retriever" in italics:

A <i>labrador retriever</i> is a big, happy friendly dog.
element.remarks: Use the <i></i> tag to visually emphasize a word or phrase. Similar to the <em><em> tag.

element.name: iframe
element.description: Defines an inline frame (i.e. a frame embedded in a document).
element.example:
This example displays an inline frame containing a job opportunities page:


<iframe src="jobs.htm" height="350px" width="350px" scrolling="yes" >
Sorry, your browser does not support inline frames. ;/iframe>
element.remarks: If a browser cannot render an inline frame, use a div to mimic the behavior. Browsers that cannot render inline frames will display the text enclosed in the <iframe></iframe> tag set instead.

element.name: ilayer
element.description: Defines a layer that is positioned within the flow of the document, rather than absolutely.
element.example:
This example displays two short text paragraphs with an ilayer between them:


<p>This is my first paragraph.</p> 
<ilayer name="dogLayer">
	<img source="dog.jpg" height="100px" width="100px" />
</ilayer>
<p>This is my second paragraph.</p>
element.remarks: Deprecated. Early Netscape only. Use a div element instead of an ilayer.

element.name: img
element.description: Defines an image object that is embedded in the document.
element.example:
Standard example

This example shows an image named "dog.jpg":

 <img src="images/dog.jpg" width="100" height="100" alt="Dog" />

Hyperlink example

This example shows an image named "dog.jpg" that is nested in a hyperlink so that it goes to a page called "dogs.htm" when a user clicsk the image:


<a href="dogs.htm">
	<img src="images/dog.jpg" width="100" height="100" alt="Dog" />
</a >
element.remarks: Using the "alt" attribute will not only display "alternate" text if an image doesn't render, it also displays the same text if a user hovers over an image. Remember to self-close your <img /> tags.

element.name: input
element.description: Defines an input element, such as a text field control or button, within a form.
element.example:
This example shows a form that collects a customer's name and phone number in two text input elements and has both submit and reset input elements:


<form action="thankyou.html" name="orderform" id="orderform" method="get" 
onsubmit="return validate();"
onreset="return confirm('Clear all fields and reset form?');">
	<input type="text" id="customerName" name="customerName" />
	<input type="text" id="phoneNumber" name="phoneNumber" />
	<br />
	<input type="submit" name="Submit" id="submit" value="Submit" />
	<input type="reset" name="Reset" id="reset" value="Reset" />
</form>
element.remarks: Use the <textarea> </textarea> element for a multiline text input area, rather than <input type="textarea" /> if possible. Remember to self-close your <input /> tags.

element.name: ins
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text has been inserted into the document.
element.example:
This example shows that the phrase "and a pug" has been inserted:

I like dogs. I have a lab <ins>and a pug</ins>.
element.remarks: The <ins></ins> tag only style text to visually show insertions.

element.name: isindex
element.description: Specifies that the document has an associated index.
element.example:
This example shows an <isindex />& element with the prompt "Keywords:" 

 <isindex href="cgi-bin/search" prompt="Keywords:" />
element.remarks: The <isindex /> element can be used in a document head or body. Remember to self-close your <isindex /> tags.

element.name: kbd
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text should be formatted as keyboard input.
element.example:
This example shows an example instructing a user to type a phrase: 

Type the following: <kbd> ipconfig </kbd>.
element.remarks: Use the <kbd></kbd> tag set to style text appropriately.

element.name: keygen
element.description: Specifies a generated key

element.name: label
element.description: Defines a label on a form.
element.example:
This example shows a form with a label that collects a customer's name and phone number:


<form action="thankyou.html" name="orderform" id="orderform" method="get" 
onsubmit="return validate();"
onreset="return confirm('Clear all fields and reset form?');">
	<label> Enter your name and phone number: </label>
	<input type="text" id="customerName" name="customerName" />
	<input type="text" id="phoneNumber" name="phoneNumber" />
	<br />
	<input type="submit" name="Submit" id="submit" value="Submit" />
	<input type="reset" name="Reset" id="reset" value="Reset" />
</form>
element.remarks: In addition to <fieldset> </fieldset>, <label> </label>, and <legend> </legend> elements, you can use <table> </table> and <div> </div> elements to improve the layout of a form.

element.name: layer
element.description: Defines a layer container holding content.
element.example:
This example displays two short text paragraphs with an ilayer between them:


<layer name="dogLayer" src="dogs.htm" left="350" top="350" height="100" width="100" />
element.remarks: Netscape only. Use a div element instead of a layer.

element.name: legend
element.description: Defines a legend for the fields on a form.
element.example:
This example shows a form with a legend that collects a customer's name and phone number:


<form action="thankyou.html" name="orderform" id="orderform" method="get" 
onsubmit="return validate();"
onreset="return confirm('Clear all fields and reset form?');">
	<legend align="top"> Customer Info </legend>
	<input type="text" id="customerName" name="customerName" />
	<input type="text" id="phoneNumber" name="phoneNumber" />
	<br />
	<input type="submit" name="Submit" id="submit" value="Submit" />
	<input type="reset" name="Reset" id="reset" value="Reset" />
</form>
element.remarks: In addition to <fieldset> </fieldset>, <label> </label>, and <legend> </legend> elements, you can use <table> </table> and <div> </div> elements to improve the layout of a form.

element.name: li
element.description: Defines a list item in an ordered list (ol) or in an unordered list (ul).
element.example:
This example shows an unordered list of dog breeds with three list items:


<ul>
	<li> Labrador retriever </li>
	<li> Golden retriever </li>
	<li> Pug </li>
</ul>
element.remarks: Use <li></li> tags to designate individual list items for both ordered (<ol> </ol>) and unordered (<ul> </ul>) lists.

element.name: link
element.description: Defines the relationship between the current document and another document.
element.example:
This example shows a <head></head> element with a link to a stylesheet:

 
<head>
	<title>Aptana Home Page</title>
	<link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css" type="text/css" />
</head>
element.remarks: Remember to self-close your <link /> tags.
Specify link tags (e.g. to stylesheets) as children of the head element.

element.name: map
element.description: Defines a client-side image map where hot regions of an image object are hyperlinked to other targets or documents.
element.example:
This example defines an area map named "navigation" with links to a home page, product page, and support page:

 <map name="navigation" > 
	<area shape="rect" coords="10,10,100,100" href="index.htm"  />
	<area shape="rect" coords="10,100,100,190" href="products.htm"  />
	<area shape="rect" coords="10,200,100,280" href="support.htm"  />
</map>
element.remarks: Remember to self-close your <area / > tags.

element.name: mark
element.description: Specifies marked text
element.example:
Consider the following quote:

Look around and you will find, no-one's really colour blind.

As we can tell from the spelling of the word, the person writing this quote is clearly not American.

element.name: marquee
element.description: Defines the enclosed text as a scrolling, sliding, or bouncing marquee region.
element.example:
This example displays the sentence "This sentence scrolls." as blinking text:

 <marquee behavior="scroll">This sentence scrolls. </marquee>
element.remarks: Limited support for <marquee></marquee> in non-Netscape browsers. Avoid using if possible.

element.name: math
element.description: Embedded Math markup language content.

element.name: menu
element.description: Specifies a list of commands
element.example:
• Help
  • About
    •

element.name: meta
element.description: Specifies general high-level information about a document.
element.example:
This example shows the <head></head> element for a company home page, including a meta tag, title, and a link to a stylesheet:

 
<head>
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" />
	<title>Aptana Home Page</title>
	<link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css" type="text/css" />
</head>
element.remarks: A <meta /> must be enclosed within the <head></head> element. You may have multiple <meta /> tags in the <head></head> element.

element.name: meter
element.description: Specifies a scalar measurement within a known range, or a fractional value
element.example: Storage space usage: 6 blocks used (out of 8 total) Voter turnout: Tickets sold:
element.remarks: Used only for measurements with a known minimum and maximum value.

element.name: nav
element.description: Specifies a section of a page that links to other pages or to parts within the page
element.example: Storage space usage: 6 blocks used (out of 8 total) Voter turnout: Tickets sold:

element.name: nobr
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text should not contain any line breaks.
element.example:
This example shows that the text should not be broken up with a line break:

 <nobr> This sentence should not be broken up with a line break no matter how long it is. </nobr>
element.remarks: <nobr /> is not a W3C-compliant tag.

element.name: noembed
element.description: Specifies alternative content to display if a client browser does not embedded objects.
element.example:
This example defines center-aligned embedded object that plays the "myMovie.mov" file and its accompanying alternative content:

 <embed src="myMovie.mov" align="center" height="350" width="350"> 
	<noembed> Please download the appropriate multimedia player.</noembed>
</embed>
element.remarks: Although the <embed></embed> tag is supported by most browsers, it is not W3C-compliant. Use <object></object> to be W3C-compliant.

element.name: noframes
element.description: Specifies alternative content to display if a client browser does not support frames.
element.example:
This example shows a frameset containing two frames--a navMenu.htm page and a home page (index.htm). The frameset is split into columns and also contains the alternative text to display if a user's browser does not support frames:


<frameset cols="20%, 80%" >
	<frame src="navMenu.htm" name="navMenu" />
	<frame src="index.htm" name="home" />
	<noframes>Sorry, your browser does not support frames.</noframes>
</frameset>
element.remarks: Nest your <noframes> </noframes> tags within a set of <frameset> </frameset>, tags.

element.name: noscript
element.description: Specifies alternative content to display if a client browser does not support scripts.
element.example:
This example shows a basic <script> element for a JavaScript script and its corresponding <noscript> element :


<script language="type/javascript">
	 <!-- JavaScript script... -->
</script>
<noscript> Your browser does not support JavaScript. </noscript>
element.remarks: <noscript> </noscript> currently only displays if a browser does not support any scripting language. It does not distinguish between scripting languages.

element.name: object
element.description: Defines an object embedded in the document.
element.example:
This example displays an object named "myDemo":


<object classid="java:myDemo.class" standby="Loading..." height="350" width="350"> 
	<param name="loop" value="2" /> 
	Sorry, if this text is displayed, your browser does not support Java.
</object>
element.remarks: Use <object></object> instead of the <applet></applet> tag.

element.name: ol
element.description: Defines an ordered (e.g. numbered) list.
element.example:
This example shows an ordered list of dog breeds with three list items. This list will be numbered by default:


<ol>
	<li>Labrador retriever</li>
	<li>Golden retriever</li>
	<li>Pug</li>
</ol>
element.remarks: Use <li></li> tags to designate individual list items for both ordered (<ol></ol>&) and unordered (<ul></ul>) lists.

element.name: optgroup
element.description: Specifies a grouping of option elements within a select element.
element.example:
This example shows a select list of dog breeds with three list items. The two large breeds are grouped together into an option group.


<select name="dog" id="dog" >
	<optgroup label= "bigDogs" >
		<option id="lab" label="lab" value="lab" > Labrador retriever </option>
		<option id="golden" label="golden" value="golden" > Golden retriever </option>
	</optgroup>
	<option id="pug" label="pug" value="pug" > Pug </option>
</select>
element.remarks: <optgroup></optgroup> tags should always be nested within a <select></select> element.

element.name: option
element.description: Specifies an option in a select (selection list) element.
element.example:
This example shows a select list of dog breeds with three list items. The two large breeds are grouped together into an option group.


<select name="dog" id="dog" >
	<optgroup label= "bigDogs" >
		<option id="lab" label="lab" value="lab" > Labrador retriever </option>
		<option id="golden" label="golden" value="golden" > Golden retriever </option>
	</optgroup>
	<option id="pug" label="pug" value="pug" > Pug </option>
</select>
element.remarks: <option></option> tags should always be nested within a <select></select> element.

element.name: output
element.description: Specifies the different types of output, such as output written by a script.
element.example: <form onsubmit="return false"> <input name=a type=number step=any> + <input name=b type=number step=any> = <output onforminput="value = a.valueAsNumber + b.valueAsNumber"></output> </form>

element.name: p
element.description: Defines a paragraph of text.
element.example:
This example displays a paragraph with a single sentence of text:

 <p>A labrador retriever is a big, happy friendly dog.</p>
element.remarks: Use CSS rules to format your paragraphs.

element.name: param
element.description: Specifies a parameter to be passed to an embedded object.
element.example:
This example displays an object named "myDemo":


<object classid="java:myDemo.class" standby="Loading..." height="350" width="350"> 
	<param name="loop" value="2" /> 
	Sorry, if this text is displayed, your browser does not support Java.
</object>
element.remarks: Remember to self-close your <param /> tags.

element.name: pre
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text is preformatted and that whitespace should be preserved appropriately. (i.e. The text will render in the browser the same as it was typed into the HTML Editor.)
element.example:
This displays the preformatted declaration of the function foo:

Declare the function foo: 
<pre>
	function foo(fooBar) {
		alert(fooBar);
	}
</pre>
element.remarks: Similar to the <code></code> tag, but the <code></code> tag does not preserve whitespace in code samples. For multiline code examples, or those with indentation, use the <pre></pre> tag.

element.name: progress
element.description: Specifies an element that represents the completion progress of a task.
element.example:
Task Progress

Progress: 0%
element.remarks: Use the progress element to display the progress of a time consuming function in JavaScript.

element.name: q
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text is a short, inline quote from another source.
element.example:
This example displays the sentence "likes big, happy dogs." as an inline quote.:

The governor was quoted as saying that she <q> likes big, happy dogs</q>.
element.remarks: Use <q></q> for short, inline quotes. Use <blockquote></blockquote> for longer quotes.

element.name: rp
element.description: Specifies an element to define what to show browsers that do not support the ruby element.

element.name: rt
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text is Ruby Text.
element.example:
This example displays the sentence "This is Ruby Text." as ruby text.:


<ruby>
	<rt> This is Ruby Text. </rt>
</ruby>
element.remarks: Use <rt></rt> tags only nested inside of <ruby></ruby> tags.

element.name: ruby
element.description: Defines a container for Ruby Text.
element.example:
This example displays the sentence "This is Ruby Text." as ruby text.:


<ruby>
	<rt> This is Ruby Text. </rt>
</ruby>
element.remarks: Use <rt></rt> tags only nested inside of <ruby></ruby> tags.

element.name: s
element.deprecated: Use CSS to format text instead.
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text should be rendered in the browser with a line drawn through it.
element.example:
This example displays the words "labrador retriever" with a line through it:

A <s>labrador retriever</s> is a big, happy friendly dog.
element.remarks: Similar to the <strike><strike> tag.

element.name: samp
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text is sample text and should be rendered in the browser appropriately.
element.example:
This example displays the words "This is sample text." as sample text:

This is what the sample looks like: <samp>This is sample text.</samp>.
element.remarks: Use the <samp></samp> tag with CSS rules to define style rules for sample text.

element.name: script
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed content is a client-side script.
element.example:
This example shows a basic <script> element for a JavaScript script:


<script language="type/javascript">
	<!-- JavaScript script... -->
</script>
<noscript> Your browser does not support JavaScript. </noscript>
element.remarks: Add the <noscript> </noscript> tags in case users have JavaScript turned off in their browsers.

element.name: section
element.description: Specifies a generic section of a document or application.
element.example:
Apples

Tasty, delicious fruit!

The apple is the pomaceous fruit of the apple tree.

Red Delicious

These bright red apples are the most common found in many supermarkets.

Granny Smith

These juicy, green apples make a great filling for apple pies.

element.name: select
element.description: Defines a selection list control in a form.
element.example:
This example shows a select list of dog breeds with three list items. The two large breeds are grouped together into an option group.


<select name="dog" id="dog" >
	<optgroup label= "bigDogs" >
		<option id="lab" label="lab" value="lab" > Labrador retriever </option>
		<option id="golden" label="golden" value="golden" > Golden retriever </option>
	</optgroup>
	<option id="pug" label="pug" value="pug" > Pug </option>
</select>
element.remarks: <option></option> tags should always be nested within a <select></select> element.

element.name: small
element.description: Decreases the font size of the enclosed text by one.
element.example:
This example displays the sentence "This sentence is small." as small text, relative to the surrounding text:

This sentence is normal-sized. <small>This sentence is small. </small>, This sentence is also normal-sized.
element.remarks: For more options and flexibility with font sizes, use CSS rules, rather than the <small></small> tag set.

element.name: source
element.description: Specifies multiple alternative media resources for media elements.
element.example:
<script>
         function fallback(video) {
           // replace <video> with its contents
           while (video.hasChildNodes()) {
             if (video.firstChild instanceof HTMLSourceElement)
               video.removeChild(video.firstChild);
             else
               video.parentNode.insertBefore(video.firstChild, video);
           }
           video.parentNode.removeChild(video);
         }
        </script>
        <video controls autoplay>
         <source src='video.mp4' type='video/mp4; codecs="avc1.42E01E, mp4a.40.2"'>
         <source src='video.ogv' type='video/ogg; codecs="theora, vorbis"'
                 onerror="fallback(parentNode)">
         ...
        </video>

element.name: span
element.description: Span element used to surround content blocks for formatting.
element.example:
This example displays the sentence "This sentence in this span is small." as small text, formatted as appropriate for the span:

This sentence is normal-sized. <span id="small" >This sentence in this span is small. </span>, This sentence is also normal-sized.
element.remarks: Use the <span></span> element for inline style formatting.

element.name: strike
element.deprecated: Use CSS to format text instead.
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text should be rendered in the browser with a line drawn through it.
element.example:
This example displays the words "labrador retriever" with a line through it:

A <strike>labrador retriever</strike> is a big, happy friendly dog.
element.remarks: Similar to the <s><s> tag.

element.name: strong
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text should be rendered in the browser as "strong" (usually bold) text.
element.example:
This example displays the words "Dog menu" and "Pug" in boldface:

From the <strong>Dog menu</strong>, select <strong>Pug.</strong>
element.remarks: Use the <strong></strong> tag to visually emphasize a word or phrase. Similar to the <b><b> tag.

element.name: style
element.description: Creates a style sheet within the document.
element.example:
This example shows a small stylesheet in the head of an HTML document. 

 
<head>
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" />
	<title>Aptana Home Page</title>
	<style type="text/css" >
		body  {background: yellow;}
				p    {color: red; font: 14pt Arial;}
	</style>
</head>
element.remarks: You can also link to external CSS style sheets to format your documents.

element.name: sub
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text should be rendered in the browser as subscript.
element.example:
This example displays a phrase in subscript:

This text is normal. <sub>This text is subscript. </sub>
element.remarks: Use the <sub></sub> tag for things like footnotes.

element.name: summary
element.description: Specifies a header for the "details" element, which is used to describe details about a document, or parts of a document.

element.name: sup
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text should be rendered in the browser as superscript.
element.example:
This example displays a phrase in superscript:

This text is normal. <sup>This text is superscript.</sup>
element.remarks: Use the <sup></sup> tag for things like showing exponents.

element.name: svg
element.description: Embedded Scalable Vector Graphics content.

element.name: table
element.description: Defines an HTML table in a document.
element.example:
This example shows a table with a header row, and three body rows:


<table>
	<tr> 
		<th>Dog Breed</th><th> Dog Name  </th>
	</tr>
	<tr> 
		<td>Labrador retriever </td>  <td> Lucky </td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
		<td>Golden retriever </td>  <td> Jordo </td>
	<tr>
	</tr>
		<td>Pug </td> <td> Bella </td>
	</tr>
</table>
element.remarks: In addition to displaying data, use <table> </ table> elements and <div></div> elements to lay out your web pages.

element.name: tbody
element.description: Groups rows in a table together into a table body.
element.example:
This example shows a table with a header row, and three body rows:


<table>
	<thead> 
		<tr> 
			<td>Dog Breed</td><td> Dog Name  </td>
		</tr>
	< /thead > 
	<tbody color="white" bgcolor="black" > 
		<tr> 
			<td>Labrador retriever </td>  <td> Lucky </td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Golden retriever </td>  <td> Jordo </td>
		<tr>
		</tr>
			<td>Pug </td> <td> Bella </td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>
element.remarks: Use <tbody> </ tbody> element to style the body of the table differently from the rest of the table.

element.name: td
element.description: Defines a single cell within a table.
element.example:
This example shows a table with a header row, and three body rows:


<table>
	<tr> 
		<th>Dog Breed</th><th> Dog Name  </th>
	</tr>
	<tr> 
		<td>Labrador retriever </td>  <td> Lucky </td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
		<td>Golden retriever </td>  <td> Jordo </td>
	<tr>
	</tr>
		<td>Pug </td> <td> Bella </td>
	</tr>
</table>
element.remarks: In addition to displaying data, use <table> </ table> elements and <div></div> elements to lay out your web pages.

element.name: textarea
element.description: Defines a multi-line text input area.
element.example:
This example shows a form that collects a customer's name and phone number in two text input elements, a textarea element for feedback, and has both submit and reset input elements:


<form action="thankyou.html" name="orderform" id="orderform" method="get" 
onsubmit="return validate();"
onreset="return confirm('Clear all fields and reset form?');">
	<input type="text" id="customerName" name="customerName" />
	<input type="text" id="phoneNumber" name="phoneNumber" />
	<textarea name="feedback" id="feedback" rows="10" cols="80" > < /textarea>
	<br />
	<input type="submit" name="Submit" id="submit" value="Submit" />
	<input type="reset" name="Reset" id="reset" value="Reset" />
</form>
element.remarks: Use the <textarea> </textarea> element for a multiline text input area, rather than <input type="textarea" /> if possible. Any text between the <textarea> </textarea> tags will be the default text for the element.

element.name: tfoot
element.description: Defines a group of rows in an HTML table as table footer rows.
element.example:
This example shows a table with a header row, and three body rows, and a footer row:


<table>
	<thead> 
		<tr> 
			<td>Dog Breed</td><td> Dog Name  </td>
		</tr>
	< /thead > 
	<tbody > 
		<tr> 
			<td>Labrador retriever </td>  <td> Lucky </td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Golden retriever </td>  <td> Jordo </td>
		<tr>
		</tr>
			<td>Pug </td> <td> Bella </td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
	<tfoot class="smalltext" > 
		<tr> 
			<td>From the article "Common Dog breeds and names".  </td>
		</tr>
	< /tfoot > 
</table>
element.remarks: Use <tfoot> </ tfoot> element to style the footer of the table differently from the rest of the table.

element.name: th
element.description: Specifies that a cell in a table is a header cell.
element.example:
This example shows a table with a header row, and three body rows:


<table>
	<tr> 
		<th>Dog Breed</th><th> Dog Name  </th>
	</tr>
	<tr> 
		<td>Labrador retriever </td>  <td> Lucky </td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
		<td>Golden retriever </td>  <td> Jordo </td>
	<tr>
	</tr>
		<td>Pug </td> <td> Bella </td>
	</tr>
</table>
element.remarks: Use the <th> </th> elements to style table header cells differently from the rest of the table.

element.name: thead
element.description: Defines a group of rows in an HTML table as table header rows.
element.example:
This example shows a table with a header row, and three body rows, and a footer row:


<table>
	<thead> 
		<tr> 
			<td>Dog Breed</td><td> Dog Name  </td>
		</tr>
	< /thead > 
	<tbody > 
		<tr> 
			<td>Labrador retriever </td>  <td> Lucky </td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Golden retriever </td>  <td> Jordo </td>
		<tr>
		</tr>
			<td>Pug </td> <td> Bella </td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
	<tfoot class="smalltext" > 
		<tr> 
			<td>From the article "Common Dog breeds and names".  </td>
		</tr>
	< /tfoot > 
</table>
element.remarks: Use <thead> </ thead> element to style the table header differently from the rest of the table.

element.name: time
element.description: Specifies a time on a 24 hour clock, or a precise date in the proleptic Gregorian calendar, optionally with a time and a time-zone offset.
element.example: http://www.web2con.com/ Web 2.0 Conference: October 5 - 19, at the Argent Hotel, San Francisco, CA

element.name: title
element.description: Specifies the title of the HTML document.
element.example:
This example shows the <head></head> element for a company home page, including a meta tag, title, and a link to a stylesheet:

 
<head>
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" />
	<title>Aptana Home Page</title>
	<link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css" type="text/css" />
</head>
element.remarks: The <head></head> element must contain a <title></title> element.

element.name: tr
element.description: Defines a row in an HTML table.
element.example:
This example shows a table with a header row, and three body rows:


<table>
	<tr> 
		<th>Dog Breed</th><th> Dog Name  </th>
	</tr>
	<tr> 
		<td>Labrador retriever </td>  <td> Lucky </td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
		<td>Golden retriever </td>  <td> Jordo </td>
	<tr>
	</tr>
		<td>Pug </td> <td> Bella </td>
	</tr>
</table>
element.remarks: Nest your <tr> </tr> elements within <table> </tabe>, <thead> </thead>, <tbody> </tbody>, and <tfoot> </tfoot> elements. A <tr> </tr> element may contain <td> </td> or <th> </th> elements.

element.name: track
element.description: The track element allows authors to specify explicit external timed text tracks for media elements. It does not represent anything on its own.
element.example: <video src="brave.webm"> <track kind=subtitles src=brave.en.vtt srclang=en label="English"> <track kind=captions src=brave.en.hoh.vtt srclang=en label="English for the Hard of Hearing"> <track kind=subtitles src=brave.fr.vtt srclang=fr lang=fr label="Franais"> <track kind=subtitles src=brave.de.vtt srclang=de lang=de label="Deutsch"> </video>

element.name: tt
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text should be rendered in the browser in a monospace font.
element.example:
This example displays words "bar" and "foo" in monospace code format:

Call the function <tt>bar</tt> on the object <tt>foo</tt>.
element.remarks: Deprecated. Use either the the <code></code> or <pre></pre> tags to render text in a monospace font.

element.name: u
element.deprecated: Use CSS to style text instead.
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text should be rendered as underlined in the browser.
element.example:
This example underlines the words "labrador retriever":

A <u>labrador retriever</b> is a big, happy, friendly dog.
element.remarks: Use the <u></u> tag to visually emphasize a word or phrase.

element.name: ul
element.description: Defines an unordered list, such as a bulleted list.
element.example:
This example shows an square bulleted of dog breeds with three list items. This list will be numbered by default:


<ul type="square">
	<li> Labrador retriever </li>
	<li> Golden retriever </li>
	<li> Pug </li>
</ul>
element.remarks: Use <li></li> tags to designate individual list items for both ordered (<ol></ol>&) and unordered (<ul></ul>) lists.

element.name: var
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text is a variable.
element.example:
This example displays words "foo" in text style used for variables:

Declare the variable <var>foo</var> and assign it a value of "bar".
element.remarks: The <var></var> tag will usually render the enclosed text as italics.

element.name: video
element.description: Specifies an element used for playing videos or movies.
element.example: Download the video file.

element.name: wbr
element.description: For a block of text enclosed by nobr tags, indicates a place where a line break may occur.
element.example:
This example shows that the text should not be broken up with a line break:

 <nobr> This sentence should not be broken up with a line break unless the line break occurs here< wbr />, but not anywhere else.. </nobr>
element.remarks: <wbr /> is not a W3C-compliant tag.

element.name: xml
element.description: Defines an area of embedded XML data.
element.example:
Embedded XML example

This example shows an XML element embedded in an HTML document:

 
<xml id="dogs">
	 <dogs>
	 	<dog id="jordo">
			<name>Jordo</name>
	 		<breed>Golden Retriever</breed>
			<weight units="lbs">100</weight>
	 	</dog>
		<dog id="lucky">
			<name>Lucky</name>
	 		<breed>Labrador Retriever</breed>
			<weight units="lbs">85</weight>
	 	</dog>
		<dog id="bella">
			<name>Bella</name>
	 		<breed>Pug</breed>
			<weight units="lbs">18</weight>
	 	</dog>
	 </dog>
</xml>

External XML file example

This example shows a link to an external XML file:

 <xml src="dogs.xml"> </xml>
element.remarks: You can either embed an XML element in your HTML document or link to a source XML document.

element.name: xmp
element.description: Specifies that the enclosed text is an example, such as a code sample.
element.example:
This displays the preformatted declaration of the function foo:

Declare the function foo: 
<xmp>
	function foo(fooBar) {
		alert(fooBar);
	}
</xmp>
element.remarks: Deprecated. Use the <pre>&</pre>& tag instead.

attribute.name: abbr
attribute.description: Abbreviation for a header cell in a table.

attribute.name: above
attribute.description: Name of the layer above the element.

attribute.name: accept
attribute.description: Specifies accepted MIME types for file uploads.

value.description: Specify a value for accept that is not on this list.

attribute.name: accept-charset
attribute.description: Comma or space-delimited list of character encodings that are accepted by the server processing the form.

value.description: Specify a value for accept-charset that is not on this list.

attribute.name: accesskey
attribute.description: Hot-key shortcut for the element.

attribute.name: action
attribute.description: URL for submitting the form.

attribute.name: align
attribute.description: Defines the alignment of the element.

value.name: absbottom
value.description: Aligns the element with the absolute bottom of the container element.

value.name: absmiddle
value.description: Aligns the element with the absolute middle of the container element.

value.name: baseline
value.description: Aligns the element with the baseline of the surrounding text or sibling element.

value.name: bottom
value.description: Aligns the element with the bottom of the surrounding text or sibling element.

value.name: center
value.description: Aligns the element with the center of the surrounding text or sibling element.

value.name: justify
value.description: Justifies the right margin of the text.

value.name: left
value.description: Aligns the element at the left side of the container element.

value.name: middle
value.description: Aligns the element with the middle the container element.

value.name: right
value.description: Aligns the element at the right side of the container element.

value.name: texttop
value.description: Aligns the element with the top of the surrounding text.

value.name: top
value.description: Aligns the element at the top of the container element.

attribute.name: alink
attribute.deprecated: Use CSS to style links instead.
attribute.description: Specifies the color for active links in the document. Specify either a color name or RGB color.
attribute.hint: [color | "transparent"]. Example values: Red, #FF0000 (#RRGGBB color code for "red"), etc.

attribute.name: allowtransparency
attribute.description: Specifies whether the background of the element may be transparent.

attribute.name: alt
attribute.description: Specifies alternative text to display if the element cannot be displayed as expected.
attribute.hint: [text]. Example values (Usually a name/description of the element): "banner.gif", "cat.jpg", etc.

attribute.name: application
attribute.description: Specifies whether the content of the element is considered an HTA application.

value.name: no
value.description: Content is considered an HTA application.

value.name: yes
value.description: Content is not considered an HTA application.

attribute.name: archive
attribute.description: URL or list of URLs that need to be preloaded for the element.

attribute.name: async
attribute.description: Execute script asynchronously.

attribute.name: autocomplete
attribute.description: Specifies whether form autocompletion, which automatically completes the fields on a form after the user has typed enough letters, is on or off.

attribute.name: autofocus
attribute.description: Automatically focus the form control when the page is loaded.

attribute.name: autoplay
attribute.description: Hint that the media resource can be started automatically when the page is loaded.

attribute.name: axis
attribute.description: Specifies a name for a group of headers.

attribute.name: background
attribute.deprecated: Use CSS to style the background instead.
attribute.description: Specifies the URL for the background image for the document or element.

attribute.name: balance
attribute.description: Number between -10000 and +10000 that specifies the sound balance for the left and right speakers.

attribute.name: behavior
attribute.description: Specifies the movement behavior of the element.

value.name: alternate
value.description: Text should cross the field in one direction, then cross the field in the opposite direction.

value.name: scroll
value.description: Text should cross the field, wrap, and then cross again.

value.name: slide
value.description: Text should cross the field and then stop when its first character reaches the other side.

attribute.name: below
attribute.description: Name of the layer below the element.

attribute.name: bgcolor
attribute.deprecated: Use CSS to style the bgcolor instead.
attribute.description: Specifies the background color for the document or element. Specify either a color name or RGB color.
attribute.hint: [color | "transparent"]. Example values: Red, #FF0000 (#RRGGBB color code for "red"), etc.

attribute.name: bgproperties
attribute.description: If set, specifies that the background image is fixed and will not scroll.

attribute.name: border
attribute.description: Width (in pixels) of the border around the element.

attribute.name: bordercolor
attribute.description: Specifies the color of the border of the element. Specify either a color name or RGB color code.
attribute.hint: [color | "transparent"]. Example values: Red, #FF0000 (#RRGGBB color code for "red"), etc.

attribute.name: bordercolordark
attribute.description: Specifies the darker color of the border of the element, if the element has a 3D effect. Specify either a color name or RGB color code.
attribute.hint: [color | "transparent"]. Example values: Red, #FF0000 (#RRGGBB color code for "red"), etc.

attribute.name: bordercolorlight
attribute.description: Specifies the lighter color of the border of the element, if the element has a 3D effect. Specify either a color name or RGB color code.
attribute.hint: [color | "transparent"]. Example values: Red, #FF0000 (#RRGGBB color code for "red"), etc.

attribute.name: bottommargin
attribute.description: Bottom margin for the body of the document.

attribute.name: cellpadding
attribute.description: Number of pixels between the content of a cell and the edge of a cell.

attribute.name: cellspacing
attribute.description: Number of pixels between cells.

attribute.name: challenge
attribute.description: Specifies the challenge attribute of the keygen element.

attribute.name: char
attribute.description: Specifies which character to use to set the alignment for the element.
attribute.remarks: Specify a period (.) to align decimal or monetary values or numbered lists.

attribute.name: charoff
attribute.description: Number of characters to offset the other column characters from the character specified by char.

attribute.name: charset
attribute.description: Specifies the character set associated with the element.

value.description: Specify a character set not on this list.

value.name: ISO-8859-3
value.description: Latin alphabet part 3 SE Europe, Esperanto, miscellaneous others.

value.name: ISO-8859-4
value.description: Latin alphabet part 4 Scandinavia/Baltics (and others not in ISO-8859-1).

value.name: ISO-8859-5
value.description: Latin/Cyrillic part 5 The languages that are using a Cyrillic alphabet such as Bulgarian, Belarusian, Russian and Macedonian.

value.name: ISO-8859-6
value.description: Latin/Arabic part 6 The languages that are using the Arabic alphabet.

value.name: ISO-8859-7
value.description: Latin/Greek part 7 The modern Greek language as well as mathematical symbols derived from the Greek.

value.name: ISO-8859-8
value.description: Latin/Hebrew part 8 The languages that are using the Hebrew alphabet.

value.name: ISO-8859-9
value.description: Latin 5 part 9 The Turkish language. Same as ISO-8859-1 except Turkish characters replace Icelandic ones.

value.name: ISO-8859-10
value.description: Latin 6 Lappish, Nordic, Eskimo The Nordic languages.

value.name: ISO-8859-15
value.description: Latin 9 (aka Latin 0) Similar to ISO 8859-1 but replaces some less common symbols with the euro sign and some other missing characters.

value.name: cp1250
value.description: Central European languages that use Latin script, (Polish, Czech, Slovak, Hungarian, Slovene, Serbian, Croatian, Romanian and Albanian).

attribute.name: checked
attribute.description: If present, specifies that the element should be checked.

attribute.name: cite
attribute.description: URL for the source of the quote.

attribute.name: class

attribute.name: clear

value.name: left

value.name: right

attribute.name: codebase

attribute.name: color

attribute.name: cols
attribute.description: Number of characters wide that the element should be.

attribute.name: colspan

attribute.name: compact

attribute.name: point-size

attribute.name: poster

attribute.name: preload
attribute.description: Specifies a hint to the user agent about what the author thinks will lead to the best user experience

value.name: none
value.description: Hints to the user agent that either the author does not expect the user to need the media resource, or that the server wants to minimise unnecessary traffic.

value.name: metadata
value.description: Hints to the user agent that the author does not expect the user to need the media resource, but that fetching the resource metadata (dimensions, first frame, track list, duration, etc) is reasonable.

value.name: auto
value.description: Hints to the user agent that the user agent can put the user's needs first without risk to the server, up to and including optimistically downloading the entire resource.

attribute.name: profile

value.description: The date and time given by the element is the publication date and time of the nearest ancestor article element

value.name: false
value.description: The date and time given by the element is not the publication date and time of the nearest ancestor article element

value.name: readonly

attribute.name: reversed
attribute.description: If present, it indicates that the list is a descending list (..., 3, 2, 1). If the attribute is omitted, the list is an ascending list (1, 2, 3, ...).

attribute.name: rightmargin
attribute.description: Right margin (in pixels) for the body of the document.

attribute.name: rows
attribute.description: Number of rows in the element.

attribute.name: rowspan
attribute.description: Number of rows that the element should span.

value.name: all

value.name: groups
value.description: Dividing rules for the thead, tbody, tfoot, or colgroup groups.

attribute.name: scheme
attribute.description: Specifies the scheme for the value of the content attribute.

attribute.name: scope
attribute.description: Specifies cells that the element is a header for.

value.name: col

value.name: colgroup
value.description: Cell is a header for the column group.

value.name: row
value.description: Cell is a header for its row.

value.name: rowgroup
value.description: Cell is a header for its row group.

attribute.name: scoped
attribute.description: Whether the styles apply to the entire document or just the parent subtree.

value.name: scoped
value.description: Apply the specified style information only to the style element's parent element (if any), and that element's descendants..

attribute.name: scroll
attribute.description: Specifies whether or not scroll bars are visible.

attribute.name: scroll
attribute.description: Specifies whether or not the element has scroll bars.

attribute.name: scrollamount
attribute.description: Specifies the number of pixels between the end of one block of content and the start of the next while scrolling.

attribute.name: scrolldelay
attribute.description: Specifies the delay (in milliseconds) between the end of one block of scrolling content and the start of the next.

attribute.name: scrolling
attribute.description: Specifies whether or not the element has scroll bars.

value.name: auto
value.description: Element has scroll bars as needed.

value.name: no
value.description: Element does not have scroll bars.

attribute.name: seamless
attribute.description: Whether to apply the document's styles to the nested content.

value.name: seamless
value.description: Apply the document's styles to the nested content.

attribute.name: selected
attribute.description: If present, specifies that the element selected by default.

attribute.name: shape
attribute.description: For an anchor that defines a hyperlink, shape of the selectable hypertext region.

value.name: circle
value.description: Use a circle-shaped area. (Specify coords to define the shape.)

value.name: poly
value.description: Use a polygon-shaped area. (Specify coords to define the shape.)

value.name: rect
value.description: Use a rectangular area. (Specify coords to define the shape.)

attribute.name: size
attribute.description: Size of the element.

value.description: Specify a size not on the list.

attribute.name: step
attribute.description: Specifies the legal number intervals for the input field.

attribute.name: span
attribute.description: Number of columns that this column should span.

attribute.name: spellcheck
attribute.description: Specifies whether the element should be spelling and grammar checked.

attribute.name: src
attribute.description: URL for the source for the element.

attribute.name: standby
attribute.description: Text content to dislay while the object associated with the element loads.

attribute.name: start
attribute.description: The ordinal value of the first list item. The default value, used if the attribute is missing or if the value cannot be converted to a number according to the referenced algorithm, is 1 if the element has no reversed attribute, and is the number of child li elements otherwise.

attribute.name: style
attribute.description: Inline style for the element.

attribute.name: summary
attribute.description: Summary of the contents of the element.

attribute.name: tabindex

attribute.name: target

value.description: Specify a target not on this list (e.g. URL).

value.name: _self

attribute.description: Specifies the color for text of the document. Specify either a color name or RGB color.

attribute.name: title
attribute.description: Short text description for the element.

value.name: range

attribute.name: type
attribute.description: Specifies the type of linked file.

value.description: Specify a file type that is not on this list.

attribute.name: type
attribute.description: Specifies the MIME type for the element.

attribute.deprecated: Use CSS to style ordered list types instead.

value.name: a

value.name: A
value.description: Upper-case alphabet list (e.g. A., B., C., etc.)

value.name: i

value.name: I

attribute.name: type
attribute.description: Specifies the MIME type for the element.

attribute.description: Specifies the type of bullet to use in an unordered list.

attribute.name: units

value.name: baseline

value.name: center
value.description: Align in the cneter of the container element.

value.name: middle
value.description: Align in the cneter of the container element.

value.name: top
value.description: Align at the top of the container element.

attribute.name: value

attribute.name: value
attribute.description: The ordinal value of the list item.

attribute.hint: [color | "transparent"]. Example values: Red, #FF0000 (#RRGGBB color code for "red"), etc.

attribute.name: volume

attribute.name: vspace

value.name: hard

attribute.name: xmlns
attribute.description: Namespace for XML-based tags.

attribute.name: z-index
